title: Packet Tracer – Logical and Physical Mode Exploration
summary: This Packet Tracer Physical Mode activity introduces students to both logical and physical network views, network device categories, wiring closets, cabling, device installation, and basic console configuration. The scenario simulates a small-to-medium business network with branch and datacenter components.

chunks.text: The activity includes: exploring the bottom toolbar, reviewing wiring closet components, connecting end devices, installing a backup router, configuring a hostname through console access, and examining other areas of the network.
The network layout mimics a typical business environment. Many devices are preconfigured. Learners can freely explore both logical and physical modes or follow structured steps.
The activity focuses primarily on Physical Mode. Users can switch between modes to compare hardware layout, cabling, rack-mounted devices, workspace navigation, and device labeling.

The toolbar includes device categories such as routers, switches, hubs, wireless devices, security appliances, and WAN emulation. Additional categories cover end devices, components, media connectors, and multiuser tools.

Inside the wiring closet, students identify racks, shelves, tables, and pegboards. Router and switch placement is shown. Devices connected to switch ALS2 include ALS1, Access_Point, and a Web Server. Laptop_1 is wirelessly linked to Access_Point and is located on the table.

Learners inspect cable types (console, copper, USB, fiber, coax). They practice connecting a PC to a switch using copper cabling and connecting a console cable from the PC to the Edge_Router for management access.
A backup router is mounted in the rack, powered on through the rear panel, and connected to a laptop using a USB-console cable because newer devices rely on USB for management connectivity.

Using the console connection via the laptop, the student enters privileged EXEC mode, opens global configuration, and changes the router's hostname to 'Edge_Router_Backup'. Packet Tracer distinguishes between the display name and actual device hostname.
Learners are encouraged to explore additional network areas like the data center and teleworker home, observing device layout and configurations in both modes.
The activity provides a .pka file for download along with a completed version. These files enable hands‑on practice.
